chunks.original_text: 则幻化奚异於生死哉？ 唯知幻化之不异生死，则死生不足以为大。 幻化不可以言浅，死生不能变幻，化自我出矣，故学幻者必本於知幻也。 虽然，知不离觉，说有觉者不离幻境，就无觉者亦不离幻，是故由知学幻以幻幻，物虽能幻，物我犹在幻，既有学幻之知，斯堕为幻之境矣。 唯真能以性觉者，诸幻尽灭。 初无有心，奚须学哉？ 然则尹文先生之不告老成子，是真能幻者矣。 老成子归，用尹文先生之言，深思三月，遂能存亡自在，幡校四时； 冬起雷，夏造冰； 飞者走，走者飞。
chunks.translated_text:
Then how do transformation and illusion differ from life and death? Only when you know that transformation and illusion are no different from life and death can life and death no longer be considered great. Transformation and illusion cannot be called shallow, nor can life and death alter transformation—transformation arises from the self. Thus, those who study illusion must base themselves on knowing illusion.

Yet knowing does not depart from awareness. To speak of the aware is not to depart from the realm of illusion, and even the unaware do not depart from illusion. Therefore, to study illusion through knowing is to use illusion to transform illusion. Though things may transform, both things and self remain within illusion. Once one possesses the knowledge of studying illusion, one already falls into the realm of illusion.

Only those who truly awaken through their inherent nature can extinguish all illusions. Without any deliberate intent, what need is there to study?

Thus, Master Yinwen’s refusal to instruct Laochengzi was the act of one who truly understood illusion. Laochengzi returned and, applying Master Yinwen’s words, pondered deeply for three months. Thereupon, he gained mastery over existence and nonexistence, commanding the seasons to shift at will. In winter, he summoned thunder; in summer, he conjured ice. What flew he made walk, and what walked he made fly.

chunks.original_text: 终身不着其术，固世莫传焉。 解曰：丽於形体，无动非幻。 造化虽妙，亦不离幻。 造化幻物，常因人为。 人为之幻，亦依天理。 造化之幻，不离阴阳。 人之幻化，不离数变。 制於阴阳则虽真亦幻，穷其数变则即幻而觉。 觉在於我，幻岂属彼？ 苟得此道矣，不特能幻物，而不幻於物尔，遂能幡校四时，更造雷冰，变易飞走，夺造化之幻矣。 且所谓幻者，果何自而然哉？ 要其所本，依於妙心，是生其体，犹如空华从空而有。 幻体虽显，幻理则妙。 显斯有幻，妙故能幻。 唯显故可得而言，唯妙故必深思三月而后得其道尔。 且古之学幻者，非曰幻可以骇俗也，故学之盖将即幻而觉其道尔。 故语其能幻，则飞走可易，雷冰可造。 及既得其道，则终身不着其术，固世莫传焉。 噫，幻化之妙若此，故尹文先生亦不自任其道，姑道老君徂西而告之之言尔。 子列子曰：善为化者，其道密庸，其功同人。 五帝之德，三王之功，未必尽智勇之力，或由化而成，孰测之哉？ 解曰：天地之所以为天地者，幻化万物也。 圣人之所以为圣人者，觉幻化之道也。 天地之幻物，阴阳迭运，寒暑审度，使万物莫不由其道而得其宜，不以幡校四时为功也。 如天地亦以冬起雷，夏造冰为幻，则物无遗类矣。 则善为化者，亦奚以显奇出异，务骇人之观听为哉？ 是以圣人之化，虽曰密庸，不可俄而测其功，则亦同於人而已。 此老成子之能幻，所以终身不着也。 孔子能之而不为，亦此道也。 五帝三王，皆古圣人也，或逊或争，因时适变，虽示智勇之功，而默运不言之妙，人能睹其功而莫测其化之之由，未足以语帝王之治也。 觉有八征，梦有六候。 奚谓八征？ 一曰故，二曰为，三曰得，四曰丧，五曰哀，六曰乐，七曰生，八曰死。 此者八征，形所接也。 奚谓六候？ 一曰正梦，二曰蘁梦，三曰思梦，四曰寤梦，五曰喜梦，六曰惧梦。 此六者，神所交也。 解曰：觉之证，梦之候，虽神形所遇，不一其理。 要其所本，唯其心之自造尔。 不识感变之所起者，事至则惑其所由然； 识感变之所起者，事至则知其所由然。 知其所由然，则无所怛。 解曰：感变之所起，不出於觉之证，梦之候，理之常尔。 识其所由然，且能无所怛，而况於知道乎？ 知道者，虽死生曾无变乎己，其视梦觉亦末矣。 一体之盈虚消息，皆通於天地，应於物类。 故阴气壮，则梦涉大水而恐惧； 阳气壮，则梦涉大火而燔，阴阳俱壮，则梦生杀。 甚饱则梦与，甚饥则梦取。 是以以浮虚为疾者，则梦扬； 以沉实为疾者，则梦溺。 藉带而寝，则梦蛇，飞鸟御发，则梦飞。 将阴梦火，将疾梦食。 饮酒者忧，歌舞者哭。 解曰：梦者，神之所遇也。 至神之道，阴阳莫测，莫之能测，则莫之能制矣。 人之为神，因精而集，寓於形体，因於阴阳，因於彼则必役於彼矣。 此一体之盈虚消息，神遇为梦，所以通於天地，应於物类，无所逃也。 故梦涉大水，梦涉大火，气实制之也。 饱而梦与，饥而梦取，欲则使之也。 或梦扬，或梦溺，则疾疠得以蠹吾之神也。 或梦蛇，或梦飞，则物类得以感吾之神也。 将阴梦火，将疾梦食，则梦想之颠倒有如此者。 饮酒者忧，歌舞者哭，则忧喜之更生有如此者。
chunks.translated_text:
Throughout his life, he never clung to his arts, and thus the world never transmitted them.

**Explanation:** That which adheres to form is never free from illusion. Though the workings of creation are wondrous, they do not depart from illusion. The illusions of creation arise constantly through human agency; the illusions of human agency, in turn, depend on heavenly principle. The illusions of creation do not depart from yin and yang; the transformations of humans do not depart from numerical change. Governed by yin and yang, even the real becomes illusion; exhausting numerical change, even illusion awakens. Awakening lies within the self—how could illusion belong to another? Once one attains this Dao, one not only illudes things without being illuded by them, but can also command the seasons to shift, conjure thunder in winter and ice in summer, reverse the flight of birds and the gait of beasts, and seize the illusions of creation itself.

Yet what, after all, gives rise to illusion? Fundamentally, it arises from the wondrous mind, which generates its substance—just as flowers in the sky emerge from emptiness. Though the substance of illusion appears, its principle remains wondrous. Appearance gives rise to illusion; wonder enables it. Only through appearance can it be spoken of; only through wonder must one ponder deeply for three months before attaining the Dao.

Moreover, those of old who studied illusion did not do so to astonish the vulgar. Their study aimed to awaken to the Dao through illusion. Thus, when speaking of their ability to illude, flight and gait could be reversed, thunder and ice could be summoned. Yet once they attained the Dao, they never clung to their arts throughout their lives, and so the world never transmitted them.

Alas! The wonder of transformation is such that even Master Yinwen did not presume to claim the Dao as his own, merely citing the words of the Old Master as he departed westward.

Master Liezi said: *"Those skilled in transformation keep their Dao hidden and ordinary, their achievements indistinguishable from others. The virtue of the Five Emperors and the accomplishments of the Three Kings were not necessarily the result of wisdom or courage alone—some arose through transformation. Who can fathom this?"*

**Explanation:** What makes heaven and earth heaven and earth is their transformation of the myriad things. What makes the sage a sage is their awakening to the Dao of transformation. The illusions of heaven and earth—yin and yang alternating, cold and heat measured—cause the myriad things to follow their Dao and attain their proper place, without boasting of commanding the seasons as an achievement. If heaven and earth were to illude by summoning thunder in winter and ice in summer, no living thing would survive. Thus, those skilled in transformation—why would they display marvels or strive to astonish the senses? Therefore, the sage’s transformations, though hidden and ordinary, cannot be swiftly discerned in their effects, yet they remain no different from others. This is why Master Laochengzi, though capable of illusion, never clung to his arts throughout his life. Confucius could have done the same but chose not to—this is the same Dao. The Five Emperors and Three Kings were all sages of old; whether yielding or contending, they adapted to their times. Though they displayed wisdom and courage, their silent, wordless wonder worked unseen. People could witness their achievements but could not fathom how they transformed—this is beyond the governance of emperors and kings.

**Awakening has eight signs; dreams have six conditions.**

What are the eight signs?
1. The familiar,
2. The intentional,
3. The attained,
4. The lost,
5. Sorrow,
6. Joy,
7. Life,
8. Death.
These eight signs are what form encounters.

What are the six conditions?
1. Ordinary dreams,
2. Troubled dreams,
3. Thoughtful dreams,
4. Waking dreams,
5. Joyful dreams,
6. Fearful dreams.
These six arise from the interplay of spirit.

**Explanation:** The signs of awakening and the conditions of dreams, though encountered by spirit and form, do not share a single principle. Fundamentally, they arise from the mind’s own creation. Those who do not recognize the origin of sensory change are perplexed when events arise; those who recognize it understand their cause. Understanding their cause, they are free from distress.

**Explanation:** The origin of sensory change does not exceed the signs of awakening and the conditions of dreams—this is the constant principle. Recognizing their cause and remaining free from distress, how much more so for those who know the Dao? Those who know the Dao see life and death as no different from themselves; their view of dreams and awakening is but a trifle.

The waxing and waning, ebb and flow of this single body all correspond to heaven and earth and respond to the kinds of things. Thus, when yin qi is strong, one dreams of wading through great waters in terror; when yang qi is strong, one dreams of traversing great fires and burning. When both yin and yang are strong, one dreams of life and death. When overly sated, one dreams of giving; when overly hungry, one dreams of taking. Those afflicted by floating emptiness dream of soaring; those afflicted by sinking solidity dream of drowning. Sleeping with a belt beneath one dreams of snakes; birds perching on one’s hair cause one to dream of flying. When yin prevails, one dreams of fire; when illness approaches, one dreams of eating. Those who drink wine dream of sorrow; those who sing and dance dream of weeping.

**Explanation:** Dreams are encounters of the spirit. The Dao of the supreme spirit is unfathomable by yin and yang, and since none can fathom it, none can control it. The human spirit gathers through essence, dwelling within the body, dependent on yin and yang. Bound to them, it is inevitably enslaved by them. Thus, the waxing and waning, ebb and flow of this single body—its spirit’s encounters become dreams, corresponding to heaven and earth, responding to the kinds of things, with no escape. Therefore, dreaming of wading through great waters or traversing great fires is governed by the strength of qi. Dreaming of giving when sated or taking when hungry is driven by desire. Dreaming of soaring or drowning is the spirit being gnawed by illness. Dreaming of snakes or flying is the spirit being stirred by the kinds of things. Dreaming of fire when yin prevails or of eating when illness approaches—such are the inversions of dream-thought. Dreaming of sorrow after drinking or weeping after singing and dancing—such are the alternations of sorrow and joy.

chunks.original_text: 夫以一身之微，百年之生，昼夜居半，一不能守其纯气，则与时盈虚，阴阳万物昼夜为吾之寇，形劳而不休，神耗而不已，终身役役，与物俱化矣，可不悟哉？ 尝究梦觉之理，夜旦之常尔。 梦之所见，虽曰神遇，实为形役。 形之役我，非形能役，我则自役。 由我役形，形反役我，我受其役，反不能制。 方其为梦，不知是梦，因觉知梦，俄而复梦，犹以为觉。 夜旦迁流而不停，终身觉梦而不悟，虽水火取与等相，初无有实，而忧惧喜乐之态真有於心。 然而觉能知梦，梦不知觉，则觉固真於梦。 觉之所为，止存於思虑之中； 梦之先知，乃见於思虑之外，则梦实灵於觉。 旦旦之觉，其云为常有伦； 昔昔之梦，其闻见常不续。 梦觉须臾之说尔，其差殊之变乃至於此，又况生死为去来之大变，苟非其人，欲无轮溺於造化，得乎哉？ 虽然，苟能早悟於梦觉，则死生之去来亦不足道矣。 冲虚至德真经解卷之五竟 冲虚至德真经解卷之六

The body, though small, endures a hundred years of life, yet day and night divide its span. If even for a moment it fails to preserve its pure qi, then with the waxing and waning of time, the interplay of yin and yang, and the myriad things of day and night, it becomes besieged. The form toils without rest, the spirit dissipates without cease, and one spends a lifetime in ceaseless labor, transforming alongside the things of the world—how can one fail to awaken?

I have examined the principles of dreaming and waking, the constancy of night and day. What appears in dreams, though called an encounter of the spirit, is in truth the servitude of the form. If the form enslaves me, it is not that the form has the power to enslave, but that I enslave myself. By my own enslavement to the form, the form in turn enslaves me, and I, subjected to its servitude, cannot master it.

When dreaming, one does not know it is a dream; upon waking, one recognizes the dream, yet soon dreams again, still believing it to be waking. Night and day flow ceaselessly, and throughout life, one alternates between waking and dreaming without realization. Though the visions of water and fire, giving and taking, are initially without substance, the states of sorrow, fear, joy, and delight arise truly in the heart.

Yet waking knows the dream, while the dream knows not waking—thus waking is surely more real than dreaming. What waking does remains confined to thought and deliberation; what dreaming foreknows appears beyond thought and deliberation—thus dreaming is indeed more numinous than waking.

The waking of each day follows a familiar order in its deeds, while the dreams of each night present sights and sounds that rarely persist. Such is the fleeting distinction between dreaming and waking, yet their divergence extends to this degree. How much greater, then, is the transformation of life and death, the vast transition of departure and return? Without the proper person, can one hope to avoid being swept away in the currents of creation?

Nevertheless, if one awakens early to the distinction between dreaming and waking, then the comings and goings of life and death are no longer worth mentioning.

*Explication of the* Chongxu Zhide Zhenjing *(The Scripture of the Dao and Its Virtue in the Most High and Pristine), Scroll Five, concludes.*

chunks.original_text: 宋杭州州学内舍生臣江遹进 穆王下 子列子曰：神遇为梦，形接为事。 故昼想夜梦，神形所遇。 故神凝者，想梦自消。 信觉不语，信梦不达，物化之往来者也。 古之真人，其觉自忘，其寝不梦，几虚语哉？ 解曰：昼之想，夜之梦。 梦也魂交，觉也形开。 昼夜迭运，物化往来，犹如空华，随起随灭。 故信觉者不可以语道，信梦者不可以为达。 虽然，神形所遇，虽合於物，究其所生，咸其自造。 故夫想梦之颠倒与夫想梦之自为，非有佗也，亦在天神之凝不凝而已。 所谓真人者，不离於精，而其神凝者也，不知悦生，不知恶死，其出不欣，其入不拒，不以心捐道，不以人助天，翛然而往，翛然而来，不逐於物化之往来，而於梦觉都无所信者也。 故能其觉自忘，而其寝不梦也。 西极之南隅有国焉，不知境界之所接，名古莽之国。 阴阳之气所不交，故寒暑亡辩； 日月之光所不照，故昼夜亡辩。 其民不食不衣而多眠，五旬一觉，以梦中所为者实，觉之所见者妄。 四海之齐，谓中央之国，跨河南北，越岱东西，万有余里。 其阴阳之审度，故一寒一暑； 昏明之分察，故一昼一夜。 其民有智有愚，万物滋殖，才艺多方，有君臣相临，礼法相持。 其所云为，不可称计。 一觉一寐，以为觉之所为者实，梦之所见者妄。 东极之北隅，有国曰阜落之国。 其土气常燠，日月余光之照，其土不生嘉苗。 其民食草根木实，不知火食，性刚悍，强弱相藉，贵胜而不尚义； 多驰步，少休息，常觉而不眠。 解曰：西极之南隅，坤兑之方也，万物由坤之致役而趋悦息之兑，故其国以梦之所为者为实。 谓之古莽之国，则其道广莫，自古以固存也，是亦西南之类也。 东极之北隅，艮震之方也，万物由艮之径路而达乎震之大涂，方将趋於相见之离，故俗常觉而不眠。 谓之阜落之国，则以物生阜而为聚落也，是亦东北之类也。 中央之国，阴阳审度，故一昼一夜，一寒一暑，以觉为实，以梦为妄，凡皆不能逃阴阳之变尔。 周之尹氏大治产，其下趣役者，侵晨昏而弗息。 有老役夫，筋力竭矣，而使之弥勤。 昼则呻呼而即事，夜则昏惫而熟寐。 精神荒散，昔昔梦为国君。 居人民之上，总一国之事； 游燕宫观，恣意所欲，其乐无比，觉则复役。 人有慰喻其懃者，役夫曰：人生百年，昼夜各分。 吾昼为仆虏，苦则苦矣； 夜为人君，其乐无比。 何所怨哉？ 尹氏心营世事，虑锺家业，心形俱疲，夜亦昏惫而寐。 背昔梦为人仆，趋走作役，无不为也； 数骂杖挞，无不至也，眠中啽呓呻呼，彻旦息焉。 尹氏病之，以访其友。 友曰：若位足荣身，资财有余，胜人远矣； 夜梦为仆，苦逸之复，数之常也。 若欲觉梦兼之，岂可得耶！ 尹氏闻其友言，宽其役夫之程，减己思虑之事，疾并少间。 解曰：昼夜各分，形神迭用。 昼劳於神者其形则佚，故夜则神佚而形劳； 昼劳其形者其神则佚，故夜则神劳而形佚。 此阴阳消长、物极则反之道也。 尹氏与其仆所以有苦佚之复而不得兼於觉梦也。 昧者不察夫盈虚之理，信觉为实，以梦为妄，知趋於昼之利害，而不暇知梦之苦佚，殊不悟使梦而无知则可矣，梦而有知则哀乐欲恶不殊於觉，又安可以为妄哉？ 尹氏知以是为疾而访其友，是或神者先受之也。

Minister Jiang Yu, an Inner Student of the Hangzhou Prefecture Academy of the Song Dynasty, respectfully presents:

**Under King Mu**

Master Liezi said: "When the spirit encounters, it becomes a dream; when form engages, it becomes an affair. Thus, daytime thoughts give rise to nighttime dreams—these are encounters of spirit and form. Therefore, when the spirit is concentrated, thoughts and dreams naturally dissipate. One who trusts waking cannot speak of the Dao; one who trusts dreams cannot be called enlightened—these are but the comings and goings of the transformations of things."

The men of old who were true persons forgot themselves in waking and slept without dreaming—how could this be mere empty words?

**Explication:**
Daytime thoughts and nighttime dreams—dreams arise from the mingling of the hun-souls, while waking is the unfolding of form. Day and night alternate in their course, the transformations of things coming and going like flowers in empty space, arising and vanishing in an instant. Thus, one who trusts waking cannot speak of the Dao, and one who trusts dreams cannot be called enlightened.

Yet though spirit and form encounter things, when one examines their origin, all is self-created. The inversions of thoughts and dreams, and the self-generated nature of thoughts and dreams—there is no other cause; it lies solely in whether the celestial spirit is concentrated or not.

The so-called true person does not depart from essence, for their spirit is concentrated. They do not delight in life nor detest death; their going forth brings no joy, their return no resistance. They do not discard the Dao with the heart, nor do they aid Heaven with human effort. They come and go with ease, unshaken by the transformations of things, and hold no trust in either dreams or waking. Thus, they forget themselves in waking and sleep without dreaming.

At the southwestern corner of the Western Limits lies a country whose borders are unknown, called the Land of Ancient Wilderness. The qi of yin and yang do not intersect there, so cold and heat are indistinguishable; the light of sun and moon does not reach it, so day and night are undifferentiated. Its people neither eat nor wear clothing but sleep often, waking once every fifty days. To them, what they do in dreams is real, while what they see in waking is illusory.

The Central Kingdom, equidistant from the four seas, spans north and south of the Yellow River and east and west of Mount Tai, extending over ten thousand li. Its yin and yang are measured precisely, so there is one cold and one heat; its divisions of dusk and dawn are clear, so there is one day and one night. Its people range from wise to foolish, its myriad things flourish, and its skills and arts are manifold. There are rulers and subjects, rites and laws. Their deeds are beyond counting. They regard what they do in waking as real and what they see in dreams as illusory.

At the northeastern corner of the Eastern Limits lies a country called the Land of Flourishing Settlements. Its earth is perpetually warm, and though the lingering light of sun and moon shines upon it, no fine crops grow there. Its people eat grass roots and tree fruits, knowing nothing of cooked food. Their natures are fierce and unyielding; the strong oppress the weak, valuing victory over righteousness. They run swiftly and rest little, remaining awake without sleep.

**Explication:**
The southwestern corner of the Western Limits is the direction of Kun and Dui. All things follow Kun’s labor and tend toward Dui’s joy and rest, so in that land, what is done in dreams is considered real. It is called the Land of Ancient Wilderness, for its Dao is vast and boundless, existing since antiquity—this is the nature of the southwest.

The northeastern corner of the Eastern Limits is the direction of Gen and Zhen. All things follow Gen’s paths to reach Zhen’s great thoroughfares, soon to advance toward Li’s mutual manifestation. Thus, its customs favor waking and eschew sleep. It is called the Land of Flourishing Settlements because things there grow abundantly and gather in communities—this is the nature of the northeast.

In the Central Kingdom, yin and yang are measured precisely, so there is one day and one night, one cold and one heat. They regard waking as real and dreams as illusory, yet none can escape the changes of yin and yang.

In the time of the Zhou, the House of Yin greatly expanded its wealth. Those who served beneath them toiled from dawn to dusk without rest. There was an old laborer whose strength was exhausted, yet he was pressed to work even harder. By day, he groaned as he toiled; by night, he sank into deep sleep, his spirit scattered and lost. Every night, he dreamed he was a lord, ruling over the people, managing the affairs of the state, wandering through palaces and gardens, indulging every desire—his joy was unmatched. Upon waking, he returned to his labors.

When others consoled him for his toil, the laborer said: "A human life spans a hundred years, divided equally between day and night. By day, I am a servant, and though it is bitter, it is bitter indeed; by night, I am a lord, and my joy is unmatched. What cause have I for complaint?"

The House of Yin was consumed by worldly affairs, its thoughts fixed on family wealth. Both mind and body were exhausted, and at night, it too sank into deep sleep. In dreams, it became a servant, running errands and performing every task, enduring scoldings and beatings without end. In sleep, it muttered and groaned until dawn.

Distressed, the House of Yin sought counsel from a friend. The friend said: "Your position brings honor, and your wealth is abundant—you surpass others by far. Yet to dream of being a servant is but the natural alternation of hardship and ease. How could you hope to have both waking and dreaming as you wish?"

Upon hearing this, the House of Yin eased the laborer’s workload and reduced its own burdensome thoughts. Its illness gradually abated.

**Explication:**
Day and night are divided, with form and spirit alternating in use. When the spirit labors by day, the body rests, so by night, the spirit rests while the body labors. When the body labors by day, the spirit rests, so by night, the spirit labors while the body rests. This is the Dao of yin and yang’s waxing and waning, of things reaching their extreme and then reversing.

Thus, the House of Yin and its servant experienced the alternation of hardship and ease, unable to have both in waking and dreaming. The ignorant, failing to understand the principle of fullness and emptiness, trust waking as real and dismiss dreams as illusory. They pursue the gains and losses of the day but pay no heed to the joys and sorrows of dreams. Little do they realize that if dreams were without awareness, it would be well, but if dreams *are* aware, then sorrow and joy, desire and aversion are no different from waking—how then can they be dismissed as illusory?

That the House of Yin recognized this as an illness and sought counsel from a friend was perhaps because the spirit had already received its warning.

chunks.original_text: 至於能宽其役夫之程，减己思虑之事，疾并少间，则其理诚可信矣。 如俾其诚之不已於己，思虑损之又损，则至神可凝，想梦自消，奚止其疾少间而已哉？ 郑人有薪於野者，遇骇鹿，御而击之，毙之。 恐人见之也，遽而藏诸隍中，覆之以蕉，不胜其喜。 俄而遗其所藏之处，遂以为梦焉，顺涂而咏其事。 傍人有闻者，用其言而取之。 既归，告其室人曰：向薪者梦得鹿而不知其处，吾今得之，彼直真梦者矣。 室人曰：若将是梦见薪者之得鹿耶？ 讵有薪者耶？ 今真得鹿，是若之梦真耶？ 夫曰：吾据得鹿，何用知彼梦我梦耶？ 薪者之归，不厌失鹿。 其夜真梦藏之之处，又梦得之之主。 爽旦，按所梦而寻，得之。 遂讼而争之，归之士师。 士师曰：若初真得鹿，妄谓之梦； 真梦得鹿，妄谓之实。 彼真取若鹿，而与若争鹿。 室人又谓梦仞人鹿，无人得鹿。 今据有此鹿，请二分之。 以闻郑君。 郑君曰：嘻士师将复梦分人鹿乎？ 访之国相。 国相曰：梦与不梦，臣所不能辩也。 欲辩觉梦，唯黄帝、孔丘。 今亡黄帝、孔丘，孰辩之哉？ 且恂士师之言可也。 解曰：人之常情，信觉为实，以其形之所接也。 谓梦为妄，以其魂之所交也。 今焉觉之所为而忘之，不几於梦乎？ 梦之所遇而有实，不几於觉乎？ 盖觉之所为，每出於有心，故易以忘神之所遇； 或出於无心，故梦则灵。 要其梦觉，初无二致，冥之则俱真，辩之则俱妄。 如仞梦为实，方其梦时，奚不知其为梦？ 以觉为实，则既已觉矣，奚为复有夫梦？ 斯人之生，适居中央之国，故其於梦觉，别之如此。 如以梦觉之理语诸古莽阜落之民，则其是非特未可定也。 郑之薪者，其初以实为梦，终则以梦为实； 取鹿者用其言而以为梦，取其鹿而争其鹿。 梦觉杂揉，真伪交驰，是非相齑，此所以必有讼也。 士师，听其讼而折之者也，将以取鹿者为是，则鹿本薪者之有； 谓薪者为是，则寻而得之。 盖出於梦，是非樊然，莫知其辩，据鹿而二分之，安可以为听讼之善乎？ 此郑君闻之所以叹而访之国相也。 然而觉梦之理，平分昼夜，信觉不语，信梦不达，唯黄帝、孔子能辩其然尔，非黄帝、孔子则是非安可以遽而折之哉？ 然则士师之二分其鹿，虽为之不得已，要其至，则二分之者其於觉梦都无所信，而无所不信者也。 虽未至於想梦自消，可谓能任之矣。 且怐士师之言，不亦可乎？ 士师，法之所在也，凡有形有右而以法为分者，是非纷然，莫适为可，皆为之於且然而已，不得已而可乎可，不亦可乎？ 宋阳里华子中年病忘，朝取而夕忘，夕与而朝忘在涂则忘行，在室则忘坐，今不识先，后不识今。 阖室毒之。 竭史而卜之，弗占；
chunks.translated_text:
As for easing the labor of one’s servants and reducing one’s own burdens of thought, if the illness finds even slight respite, then the principle may indeed be trusted. But if one truly ceases to weary the self, diminishing thoughts layer by layer, then the spirit may congeal, and dream-visions dissolve—how could this merely bring slight respite to the illness?

There was a man of Zheng who gathered firewood in the wilds when he encountered a startled deer. He chased it down and struck it dead. Fearing others would see, he hastily concealed it in a ditch, covering it with plantain leaves, overcome with joy. Soon after, he forgot where he had hidden it and took it all for a dream. As he walked along, he hummed of the affair. A passerby heard him, followed his words, and took the deer. Upon returning home, he told his wife, “A firewood-gatherer dreamed he had caught a deer but forgot where it was. Now I have it—he was truly dreaming!” His wife said, “Is it not you who dreamed of the firewood-gatherer catching the deer? Was there ever a firewood-gatherer? Now that you truly have the deer, is your dream not real?” The man replied, “I have the deer in hand—why trouble myself over whether he dreamed or I dreamed?”

The firewood-gatherer returned, vexed at losing the deer. That night, he truly dreamed of the hiding place and of the one who had taken it. At dawn, he followed his dream and found it. They took their dispute to court, where the magistrate ruled: “You first truly caught the deer but falsely called it a dream; now you truly dreamed of the deer but falsely call it real. He truly took your deer, yet you dispute it with him. Your wife claims both dreamed of the deer, so no one truly has it. Since the deer is now here, let it be divided in two.” He reported this to the lord of Zheng, who exclaimed, “Ah! Is the magistrate about to dream of dividing another’s deer?” He consulted his prime minister, who said, “Dream or not—a matter I cannot discern. To distinguish waking from dreaming, only the Yellow Emperor or Confucius could do so. Now that they are gone, who can decide? Yet perhaps the magistrate’s words may suffice.”

The explanation: It is human nature to trust waking as real, for it is what the body touches, and to dismiss dreams as illusory, for they are but the wanderings of the soul. Yet if one forgets what one does while awake, is this not akin to dreaming? And if what one encounters in dreams proves real, is this not akin to waking? For waking acts often stem from intention, so the spirit easily forgets them; but dreams may arise without intent, so the spirit remains sharp. In essence, dreaming and waking are not two different things—obscure them, and both are real; scrutinize them, and both are illusory. If one insists dreams are real, then while dreaming, why does one not know it is a dream? If one insists waking is real, then once awake, why does one still have dreams?

This man lived in the central kingdom, so he distinguished dreaming and waking thus. Had one spoken of this principle to the ancient tribes of the wilds, their judgments would surely differ. The firewood-gatherer of Zheng first took reality for a dream, then took a dream for reality. The one who took the deer followed his words and treated it as a dream, yet claimed the deer and disputed it. Dream and waking intertwined, truth and falsehood raced, right and wrong clashed—hence the lawsuit. The magistrate, who adjudicates disputes, faced a dilemma: if he sided with the taker, the deer originally belonged to the firewood-gatherer; if he sided with the gatherer, the taker had followed the dream to find it. Since it all arose from a dream, right and wrong were tangled, with no clear resolution. To divide the deer in two—how could this be a just verdict? This is why the lord of Zheng sighed and consulted his prime minister.

Yet the principle of waking and dreaming divides day and night equally. Trusting waking alone leaves one mute; trusting dreams alone leaves one lost. Only the Yellow Emperor and Confucius could discern the truth—without them, how could right and wrong be swiftly decided? Thus, though the magistrate’s division of the deer was a last resort, in the end, he neither trusted nor distrusted waking or dreaming—he trusted nothing, yet trusted all. Though he did not reach the point where dream-visions dissolve, he may be said to have borne the burden well. And was not the magistrate’s judgment, after all, acceptable?

The magistrate represents the law. Where there are forms and evidence, and the law must decide, right and wrong become tangled, with no clear answer. One can only act as circumstances permit—is this not acceptable when no better course exists?

In the Yang district of Song, there was a man named Hua Zi who, in middle age, suffered from forgetfulness. What he took in the morning he forgot by evening; what he received at dusk he forgot by dawn. On the road, he forgot to walk; at home, he forgot to sit. He did not recognize what came before or after. His household was distressed. They exhausted divination and sought omens, but to no avail.

chunks.original_text: 谒巫而祷之，弗禁； 谒医而攻之，弗已。 鲁有儒生自媒能治之，华子之妻子以居产之半请其方。 儒生曰：此固非卦兆之所占，非祈请之所祷，非药石之所攻。 吾试化其心，变其虑，庶几其瘳乎？ 於是试露之，而求衣，饥之，而求食； 幽之，而求明。 儒生欣然告其子曰：疾可已也。 然吾之方密，传世不以告人。 试屏左右，独与居室七日。 从之。 莫知其所施为也，而积年之疾，一朝都除。 解曰：理涉於情伪则卦兆可占，为见於利害则祈请可祷，疾得於嗜欲则药石可攻。 迷忘之疾，荡荡然不觉天地之有无，又何占相、祈祷、药石之所能已乎？ 露之而求衣，未能忘寒暑也； 饥之而求食，未能忘形体也； 幽之而求明，未能忘好恶也。 由是知华子之忘特以疾而有所蔽尔，非真能忘世态者。 故儒生欣然知其疾之可已也。 如真忘者，虽造化亦末如之何矣，岂儒生浅术之所能已哉？ 儒以诗礼发冢，最为害道之大原者。 其所以使斯民离实学伪，亦有以密移而罔觉之，使人由之而不知也。 故自以谓其方密传世，必屏左右而独与居也。 与之居七日，则浑沌死，而视听食息均於人矣。 故积年之疾一朝都除。 华子既悟，乃大怒，黜妻罚子，操戈逐儒生。 宋人执而问其故。 华子曰：曩吾忘也，荡荡然不觉天地之有无。 今顿识既往，数十年来，存亡得失，哀乐好恶，扰扰万绪起矣。 吾恐将来之存亡得失、哀乐好恶之乱吾心如此也，须臾之忘，可复得乎？ 子贡闻而怪之，以告孔子。 孔子曰：此非汝所及乎。 顾谓颜回记之。 解曰：真之难遇而伪之易以乱人也久矣。 所乐在於真，则万物不足以易其好，虽妻子之爱为可割矣。 所物不足以拟其尊，虽儒生之道不足守矣。 故华子既悟，则黜妻罚子，操戈逐儒生也。 华子知忘之为可乐，则宜於世累能忘之而弗念矣。 犹恐外物之乱其心而不复得须臾之忘，又况於初不知忘之为可乐而日趋於是非之涂。 若华氏方且以华子之忘为阖室之毒，儒生方且欣其疾之可已，则其心之淆乱何如耶？ 所谓宋阳里华子者，阳则以生育长养为事，华则得阳而蕃鲜，是皆趋於扰扰之涂者也。 中年病忘，则落其华而反本焉。 及其既悟，则复趋於胶扰之涂矣。 反常者兑之悦泽，生出者震之决躁，故华子既悟，乃大怒也。 子贡居言语之科，方且以贤於方人，见斥於孔子； 若颜子则能忘仁义，忘礼乐，屡进而至於坐忘矣。 故孔子顾谓颜回记之。 秦人逢氏有子，少而惠，及壮而有迷罔之疾。 闻歌以为哭，视白以为黑，飨香以为朽，尝甘以为苦，行非以为是； 意之所之，天地四方，水火寒暑，无不倒错者焉。 杨氏告其父曰：鲁之君子多术艺，将能已乎？ 汝奚不访焉。 其父之鲁，过陈，遇老聪，因告其子之证。 老聃曰：汝庸如汝子之迷乎？ 今天下之人皆惑於是非，昏於利害。 同疾者多，固莫有觉者。 且一身之迷不足倾一家，一家之迷不足倾一乡，一乡之迷不足倾一国，一国之迷，不足倾天下。 天下尽迷，孰倾之哉？ 向使天下之人，其心尽如汝子，汝则反迷矣。 哀乐、声色、臭味、是非，孰能正之？ 解曰：歌哭、白黑、香臭、甘苦，至於天地四方，水火寒署，纷纷之名，同一妙本，初无二致。 由彼妄情，有於爱恶，物物分辩，种种假名，寻名求实，执着不易，莫有觉者。

They sought out shamans to pray for him, but the condition remained; they consulted physicians to treat him, but it did not cease. In Lu there was a Confucian scholar who offered his services, claiming he could cure Hua Zi. His wife and children offered half their property in exchange for the remedy. The scholar said: "This is not a matter for divination or omens, nor for prayers or supplications, nor for medicine or stone needles. Let me attempt to transform his heart and alter his thoughts—perhaps then he may recover."

Thereupon, they exposed him to the elements so that he sought clothing; they starved him so that he sought food; they confined him in darkness so that he sought light. The scholar joyfully told Hua Zi’s son: "The illness can be cured. However, my method is secret and not to be passed down to others. Let me send away all attendants and remain alone with him in seclusion for seven days." They complied. None knew what he did, yet an affliction of many years vanished in a single morning.

The explanation states: When principles are entangled with falsehood, divination may be consulted; when matters are bound to profit and harm, prayers may be offered; when illness arises from indulgence, medicine may be applied. But the malady of forgetfulness is so vast that one is unaware of the existence of heaven and earth—how could divination, prayers, or medicine cure it? Exposing him to seek clothing shows he had not forgotten cold and heat; starving him to seek food shows he had not forgotten the body; confining him in darkness to seek light shows he had not forgotten likes and dislikes. Thus, Hua Zi’s forgetfulness was merely an obstruction caused by illness, not true oblivion of worldly affairs. Therefore, the scholar rejoiced, knowing the illness could be cured. If it were true oblivion, even the workings of creation could do nothing—how could a Confucian’s shallow art suffice?

Confucians, who exhume graves under the guise of poetry and ritual, are the greatest corrupters of the Dao. Their methods subtly mislead the people, making them depart from truth and embrace falsehood without awareness. Thus, the scholar insisted his method was secret and must be transmitted only in strict privacy. After seven days together, the chaos within Hua Zi perished, and his sight, hearing, eating, and breathing became like those of ordinary men. The long-standing illness vanished in a single morning.

Once Hua Zi awoke, he flew into a great rage, cast out his wife, punished his children, and brandished a halberd to drive away the scholar. The people of Song seized him and demanded an explanation. Hua Zi said: "Before, when I was forgetful, I was vast and unaware of the existence of heaven and earth. Now, suddenly recalling the past, decades of life and death, gain and loss, sorrow and joy, likes and dislikes—all ten thousand threads surge forth. I fear that future matters of life and death, gain and loss, sorrow and joy, and likes and dislikes will disturb my heart like this. Can I ever again attain even a moment’s forgetfulness?"

Zi Gong heard of this and found it strange. He reported it to Confucius, who said: "This is not something within your grasp." Then he turned to Yan Hui and told him to record it.

The explanation states: The difficulty of encountering truth and the ease with which falsehood confuses people have persisted for a long time. When one’s joy lies in truth, the myriad things cannot alter one’s preferences, and even the love of wife and children may be forsaken. Nothing in the world can compare to its worth, and even the Confucian Dao is not worth adhering to. Thus, once Hua Zi awoke, he cast out his wife, punished his children, and drove away the scholar with a halberd. Knowing the joy of forgetfulness, he should have been able to forget worldly burdens without a second thought. Yet he still feared external things would disturb his heart and prevent even a moment’s forgetfulness—how much worse for those who never knew the joy of forgetfulness and daily rush toward the path of right and wrong? When Hua Zi’s family regarded his forgetfulness as a household affliction, and the scholar rejoiced at curing his illness, how utterly confused their hearts must have been!

The man called Hua Zi of Yang district in Song: "Yang" pertains to growth and nurturing, while "Hua" (flourishing) thrives under yang—both incline toward the path of turmoil. In middle age, he fell ill with forgetfulness, shedding his flourishing and returning to the root. But once awakened, he again rushed toward the path of entanglement. The reversal of the norm is the joyous sheen of *Dui*; the emergence of life is the hasty decisiveness of *Zhen*. Thus, Hua Zi flew into a great rage upon awakening.

Zi Gong belonged to the category of eloquence, considering himself superior to others in discernment, yet he was rebuked by Confucius. Yan Hui, however, could forget benevolence and righteousness, forget ritual and music, and repeatedly advanced until he attained "sitting in forgetfulness." Therefore, Confucius turned to Yan Hui to record this.

Among the Feng clan of Qin there was a man whose son was clever in youth but developed a bewildering illness in adulthood. He heard singing and mistook it for weeping; saw white and thought it black; smelled fragrance and deemed it rotten; tasted sweetness and found it bitter; walked correctly and believed it wrong. Wherever his mind wandered—heaven and earth, the four directions, water and fire, cold and heat—nothing was not inverted.

The Yang family told his father: "The gentlemen of Lu possess many arts and skills—perhaps they can cure him? Why not seek them out?" His father traveled to Lu and, passing through Chen, encountered Lao Dan. He described his son’s symptoms. Lao Dan said: "Are you any less deluded than your son? Today, the people of the world are all confused by right and wrong, blinded by profit and harm. Those with the same illness are many, yet none are awakened. Moreover, the delusion of one person is not enough to overturn a household; the delusion of a household is not enough to overturn a village; the delusion of a village is not enough to overturn a state; the delusion of a state is not enough to overturn the world. If the whole world were deluded, who would overturn it? If all the people of the world were like your son, then you would be the deluded one. Joy and sorrow, sound and color, scent and taste, right and wrong—who can correct them?"

The explanation states: Singing and weeping, white and black, fragrance and stench, sweetness and bitterness—even heaven and earth, the four directions, water and fire, cold and heat—all these manifold names share a single wondrous root, originally without distinction. It is through deluded emotions that likes and dislikes arise, that things are distinguished, and that various false names are assigned. Seeking reality through names, clinging stubbornly without change—none are awakened.

In the Yang district of Song, there was a man named Hua Zi who, in middle age, suffered from forgetfulness. What he took in the morning he forgot by evening; what he received at dusk he forgot by dawn. On the road, he forgot to walk; at home, he forgot to sit. He did not recognize what came before or after. His household was distressed. They exhausted divination and sought omens, but to no avail.

chunks.original_text: 即其一端而论之，以白为白，是从众也； 以白为黑，是从我也。 从我则众疑，从众则我惑。 彼我异言，白黑殊名。 名言虽殊，体性不动，是以名言之异。 众寡相倾，寡不敌众，以迷导迷，沦胥以溺而不反矣，安可遽以众人之同疾为是，一人之独觉者为非耶？ 杨氏以为我之道倾天下，方且与儒墨相为是非白黑，故为逢氏病之，而俾之访於鲁之多术者。 逢氏则逢物而偶之者也，故少而惠，长而以迷罔为疾。 且吾之此言未必非迷，而况鲁之君子迷之邮者，焉能解人之迷哉？ 荣汝之粮，不若遗而归也。 解曰：天下本无正是，大道不涉言诠。 但圣人垂世立教者，不免於云云耳。 又恐学者以众人之言为非而以圣人之言为是，遂认而不舍，守而不忘，谚所谓黄金虽贵，入眼成翳。 故老子曰：吾之此言未必非迷，况鲁之君子立仁义忠信之教，垂诗书礼乐之文，迷中之最迷者，又安能解人之迷哉？ 荣汝之粮，不如遄归，盖使之返照，求之於内耳。 燕人生於燕，长於楚，及老而还本国，过晋国，同行者诳之，指城曰：此燕国之城。 其人愀然变容。 指社曰：此若里之社。
chunks.translated_text:
"To examine but one aspect: to take white as white is to follow the multitude; to take white as black is to follow oneself. Following oneself invites doubt from the many; following the many brings confusion to oneself. Their words differ, mine differ—white and black bear distinct names. Though names and words diverge, the essence remains unmoved; it is only in names and words that distinctions arise. The many and the few contend, and the few cannot withstand the many. Leading delusion with delusion, all sink together and do not return—how can one hastily deem the shared affliction of the multitude as right and the solitary awakening of the one as wrong?

Master Yang believed his Dao could overturn the world, yet he still contended with the Confucians and Mohists over right and wrong, white and black. Thus, Feng was troubled by this and sent him to seek counsel from the many masters of Lu. Feng was one who met things and matched them, hence in youth he was clever, but in maturity he took delusion and confusion as his malady.

Moreover, my own words here are not necessarily free from delusion—how much less can the gentlemen of Lu, those couriers of delusion, resolve the delusions of others? Better to take your provisions and return home.

The explanation states: The world originally has no fixed right; the great Dao does not enter into verbal explanations. Yet the sages, in bequeathing teachings to the world, could not avoid such discourse. They also feared that learners would take the words of the multitude as wrong and the words of the sages as right, clinging to them without release, guarding them without forgetting—as the saying goes, 'Gold, though precious, becomes a film in the eye.' Thus Laozi said: 'My own words here are not necessarily free from delusion. How much less can the gentlemen of Lu, who establish teachings of benevolence, righteousness, loyalty, and trust, and bequeath the texts of the *Odes*, *Documents*, rites, and music—the most deluded of the deluded—resolve the delusions of others?' Take your provisions and hasten home, for this is meant to turn you inward, to seek within.

His traveling companions deceived him, pointing to a city and saying, 'This is the city of Yan.' The man’s expression changed sorrowfully. They pointed to a shrine and said, 'This is the village shrine of your homeland.'"

chunks.original_text: 乃喟然而叹。 指舍曰：此若先人之庐。 乃涓然而泣。 指垄曰：此若先人之冢。 其人哭不自禁。 同行者哑然大笑，曰：予昔给若，此晋国耳。 其人大惭。 及至燕，真见燕国之城社，真见先人之庐冢，悲心更微。 解曰：传教者有真伪，受道者有先后，先入者为主，后入者为客。 今之学者，先遇一师，传以伪法，遂认而守之，谓其无以复加矣。 数年之后，忽遇真师，传以真理，反执而不信，至于终身不悟，良可悲哉。 故御寇设此燕人过晋之喻。 斯人也，生于燕而长于楚，既老而归。 过於晋国，同行者诳之曰：此燕之城也。 其人愀然变容。 指社曰：此若里之社也。 乃喟然而欺。 指舍曰：此若先人之庐也。 乃涓然而泣。 指垄曰：此若先人之坟墓也。 乃哭不自禁。 同行者哑然而大笑，曰：此晋国也，向吾给若。 其人大惭。 及至燕国，真见先人之庐冢，悲心遂消沉而不能更发矣。 盖境之感人，初见则动情也，深再见则视犹平常。 且父母之邦，本以乐生也，今愈近而愈蹙，终至於涕泣而止尔，何生之乐哉？ 又其所谓燕者，初非燕国，实晋城尔，彼以伪给真，此以真信妄，自给之者以观，真足资其默笑尔。 由是知人之所谓内外亲疏、喜怒哀乐，未有不犹燕人之给也。 从而亲疏忧乐之，亦未有不见笑於造物者，犹燕之人也。 如亦悟其不真，则亦必思其当悲忧之时，何至而能尔也？ 然而亲疏不在物而在我，真伪不在境而在心，心真则虽伪亦真，心惑则虽真亦伪。 向俾晋人终不自言其给，则燕人之情终亦不易矣。 及知其为给，虽真见先人之庐冢，悲心更微矣。 何则？ 人之心未始不真，一诱於人，伪欲复於真，不可得矣。 是以燕之人真情一散，漫不可复。 其后彼虽以诚而来，我亦审其无妄矣，欲强之悲，终亦弗能矣，可不慎哉？ 尝原老列之教，大抵期镇斯民以无名之朴，使之不荡於伪而已，不以治斯民於既浇漓之后为教也。 故《道经》终言无名之朴，亦将不欲以静，天下将向正，而《穆王》之篇终之以此也。 穆王解 由皇而下至於王功，虽曰道之屡降，要帝王之应世，咸本於道，皆圣人之所为也，特其因时适变。 居帝者之世，不得不为帝功； 至王者之时，不得不为王业尔。 治至於王功而末矣，虽贤人可久之德，亦庶几及之矣，故禹汤文武同为王功。 启之贤亦足以承禹之道，成王之中才亦能特守文武之业也。 至於穆王，道不足以传，化人之妙不盈于德而谐於乐，周道自是而衰矣。 於帝言其盛，於王言其衰，始终之理也。 且五帝之德，三王之功，其道密庸，或由幻化，直若一梦尔。 故此篇剧育觉梦之理，有若古莽之国，以梦中所为为实者； 有若阜落之民，常觉而不眠者。 役思虑於昼则昔昔梦为人仆，劳形体於昼则昔昔梦为人君。 至於争鹿之讼，则觉梦又不可得而辩矣。 圣人应世之迹，如斯而已。 诚能审觉梦之道，则知病迷者非本迷，病忘者非本忘。 是非美恶，同之於道。 道化德业，同於一致。

Then he sighed deeply. Pointing to a house, they said, "This is your ancestors’ dwelling." He wept silently. Pointing to a mound, they said, "This is your ancestors’ grave." The man could not restrain his sobs. His companions burst into laughter, saying, "We deceived you before—this is but Jin." The man was overcome with shame.

When at last he reached Yan and truly beheld the city and village shrine of his homeland, when he truly saw his ancestors’ dwelling and grave, his sorrow had already grown faint. The explanation follows: Those who transmit teachings may be true or false; those who receive the Dao may do so early or late. What enters first becomes the master; what enters later becomes the guest. Today’s scholars, having first encountered a teacher who transmits false methods, cling to them and guard them, believing nothing could surpass them. Years later, should they suddenly meet a true teacher who imparts the true principle, they cling to disbelief instead, and to the end of their days remain unenlightened—how lamentable!

Thus Liezi set forth this parable of the Yan man passing through Jin. This man, born in Yan and raised in Chu, returned in old age. Passing through Jin, his companions deceived him, saying, "This is the city of Yan." His expression changed sorrowfully. Pointing to a shrine, they said, "This is the village shrine of your homeland." He sighed deeply. Pointing to a house, they said, "This is your ancestors’ dwelling." He wept silently. Pointing to a mound, they said, "This is your ancestors’ grave." He could not restrain his sobs. His companions burst into laughter, saying, "This is Jin—we deceived you before." The man was overcome with shame.

When at last he reached Yan and truly saw his ancestors’ dwelling and grave, his sorrow had already subsided and could not arise again. For the heart is moved by what it first encounters; upon seeing it deeply a second time, it regards it as ordinary. Moreover, one’s homeland is meant to be a place of joy in life, yet the nearer he drew, the more his distress grew, until at last he could only weep—where was the joy in living?

What he had taken for Yan was not Yan at all, but merely a city of Jin. They had deceived him with falsehood, and he had believed it as truth. From the deceivers’ perspective, this was truly cause for mockery. Thus we know that what people call inner and outer, near and far, joy and anger, sorrow and delight, are no different from the Yan man’s deception. In their attachments to near and far, sorrow and joy, they too are surely laughed at by the Creator, just as the Yan man was.

If one could awaken to the unreality of such things, one would surely reflect: in times when sorrow and grief arise, how could they persist? Yet near and far do not lie in things but in oneself; truth and falsehood do not lie in circumstances but in the heart. When the heart is true, even the false becomes true; when the heart is deluded, even the true becomes false.

Had the people of Jin never revealed their deception, the Yan man’s emotions would never have changed. But once he knew he had been deceived, even when he truly saw his ancestors’ dwelling and grave, his sorrow grew faint. Why? The human heart is not inherently untrue, but once led astray by others, it cannot return to truth. Thus the Yan man’s true feelings, once scattered, could never be restored. Though later they came to him in sincerity, he examined them for falsehood, and even when he forced himself to grieve, he could not—how could he not be cautious?

Tracing the teachings of Laozi and Zhuangzi, we find their great aim was to anchor the people in nameless simplicity, preventing them from being swayed by falsehood—not to govern them after their nature had already been corrupted. Thus the *Daodejing* concludes with nameless simplicity, teaching that one should not desire stillness, and the world will naturally turn toward uprightness. The *King Mu* chapter ends with this as well.

The *King Mu* commentary: From the August Thearch down to the achievements of kings, though it is said the Dao descended repeatedly, the responses of emperors and kings to the world all arose from the Dao and were the work of sages, differing only in their adaptation to the times. In the age of the Thearch, one could not but perform the works of the Thearch; in the age of the King, one could not but perform the works of the King. Governance reaches its end in the works of the King, and even the enduring virtue of the worthy nearly attains it. Thus Yu, Tang, Wen, and Wu all performed the works of kings. Qi’s worthiness was sufficient to carry on Yu’s Dao, and King Cheng’s mediocrity was enough to preserve the legacy of Wen and Wu.

By the time of King Mu, the Dao was insufficient to be transmitted, and the marvel of transforming others did not fill his virtue but harmonized with music—from this point, the Zhou Dao declined. In speaking of the Thearch, we speak of its flourishing; in speaking of the King, we speak of its decline—this is the principle of beginning and end.

Moreover, the virtue of the Five Thearchs and the achievements of the Three Kings, though their Dao was profound and constant, were at times illusory, like a dream. Thus this chapter vividly illustrates the principle of dreaming and waking, as if there were an ancient, wild land where people took their dreams as reality, or rustic folk who remained awake and never slept. Those who exhaust their thoughts by day dream nightly of being servants; those who labor their bodies by day dream nightly of being lords. As for the dispute over the deer, waking and dreaming become indistinguishable.

The traces of sages in responding to the world are like this. If one can discern the way of waking and dreaming, one knows that those who suffer delusion are not deluded by nature, nor are those who suffer forgetfulness forgetful by nature. The dust and chaff of the world suffice to mold even Yao and Shun with abundance—how much more the achievements of kings? Tracing the origins of governance, it began with the Three Sovereigns. In that era, the Dao was left to nurture the world, and the people used knotted cords for records. At rest, they were at ease; in motion, they were content—this was the height of good governance.

Yet once the Dao was set aside for governance, the turning of the times inevitably led to the virtue of the emperors. The rule of the emperors—such as the Yellow Emperor, Yao, and Shun, who governed the world by merely draping their robes—was indeed flourishing, yet their virtue was already manifest. It must progress to the kingship of Tang and Wu, where all recognize the kingly achievements appearing in the time of Yu of Xia, though none realize its beginnings trace back to before the Three Sovereigns, and its remnants endure for a thousand generations thereafter.

Thus, the descent of the Dao is like water leaving its source: its flow is ceaseless, and as it drifts ever farther from its origin, it can never return. Zhuangzi spoke of the Yu clan as those who "summoned benevolence and righteousness to disturb the world," and of the sages as those who "could not bear the harm of one age but thereby sowed the calamities of ten thousand generations"—this is what he meant.

Nevertheless, the sage who can wield the Dao to guide the times, not following the world’s descent, may bring even the kingship of the Zhou dynasty to a state where the people’s customs differ not from the age of utmost virtue. This is the teaching bequeathed by Master Liezi, a hope for all generations, an encounter that may come at any dawn or dusk.

chunks.original_text: 此吾昔日之言尔，请以今言为正也。 汝徒知乐天知命之无忧，未知乐天知命有忧之大也。 解曰：颜子之乐在道，孔子之忧以人。 由众人以观，唯颜子为独乐； 由颜子以观，唯孔子为独忧。 天之所与，乐之而不辞，谓之乐天； 命之所制，顺之而不逆，谓之知命。 能乐天而不能知命，能知命而不能乐天，皆不足以为不忧。 虽乐天知命则穷亦乐，通下乐所乐非穷通，是所以不忧也。 颜子得是道矣，故居於人不堪之忧而能不改其乐也。 虽然，孔子行年六十而六十化。 始时所是，卒而非之。 以乐天知命为不忧，始之所是也。 以乐天知命为忧之大，今之所言也。 颜子之於孔子，得其行而未得其所以行，所以援琴而歌，而不能与圣人同忧也。 且皆圣人之言也，岂真有迕而不合哉？ 因时适变，姑请以今言为正尔。 至於真乐真知，则今昔之言又乌知辩？ 今告若其实：修一身，任穷达，知去来之非我，亡变乱於心虑，尔之所谓乐天知命之无忧也。 曩吾修诗书，正礼乐，将以治天下，遗来世； 非但修一身，治鲁国而已。 而鲁之君臣日失其序，仁义益衰，情性益薄。 此道不行一国与当年，其如天下与来世矣。 吾始知诗书礼乐无救於治乱，而未知所以革之之方，此乐天知命者之所忧。 虽然，吾得之矣。 夫乐而知者，非古人之谓所乐知也。 无乐无知，是真乐真知。 故无所不乐，无所不知，无所不忧，无所不为。 诗书礼乐，何弃之有。 革之何为？ 解曰：圣也者，德之极而道之至也。 谓之圣人，则心凝形释，都无所爱惜，都无所畏忌，当有何忧哉？ 虽仁者犹能不忧，而况於孔子集圣人之大成者，其果有忧乎？ 如未免於有忧，则不可以言圣矣。 谓圣人为有忧，是不知圣人者也。 今而自以为忧之大而形於色者，盖圣人者，万物之所系，一化之所待，而自任以天下之重者也。 以乐天知命，修一身，任穷达，知去来之非我，止变乱於心虑，我则不忧矣，安能使斯民皆无忧乎？ 彼民未尽无忧，则圣人安能独无忧乎？ 非特忧在於当年，其忧又有及於来世。 方来之世为无穷，斯民之忧为无尽，圣人之忧亦与之为无尽，则其为忧也不亦大乎？ 又况修诗书，正礼乐，将以求治而其道不行，以诗书礼乐为无救於治乱，思欲革之而未知其方，安得而无忧乎？ 何则？ 六经，先王之陈迹也，岂其所以迹哉？ 夫迹履之所出，而迹岂履哉？ 虽然，迹虽不可守而履亦不可废也。 故诗书礼乐，弃之则无以为治，即之则不能为治。 今而以乐天知命为不忧，是并与其履而弃之矣，又何以为治哉？ 是以谓之乐天，未免於有所乐也。 谓之知命，未免於有所知也。 有所乐则必有所忧，有所知则必有所遗，唯得所谓真乐真知，则无乐无知矣。 无乐无知则无所不乐，无所不知，无所不忧，无所不为，忧乐两忘。 为无为，俱遣诗书礼乐，亦不必弃而革，而天下可治，来世可遗也。 此《易》所谓鼓万物而不与圣人同忧也。 孔子所以删《诗》定《书》，系《易》作《经》，谆谆於垂训者，盖以此也。 颜回北面拜乎曰：回亦得之矣。 出告子贡。 子贡茫然自失，归家淫思七日，不寝不食，以至骨立。 颜回重往喻之，乃反丘门，弦歌诵书，终日不辍。 解曰：颜子尝请行於孔子而将之卫矣，孔子以为若殆往而刑尔，是或未得所谓乐天知命有忧之大而然欤。
chunks.translated_text:
"This was my teaching of former days—pray let my present words be taken as correct. You merely know that rejoicing in Heaven and knowing fate bring no sorrow, yet do not know that rejoicing in Heaven and knowing fate entail a sorrow of great magnitude."

*Explanation:* Yan Hui’s joy lies in the Dao, while Confucius’s sorrow concerns humanity. From the perspective of the multitude, only Yan Hui is uniquely joyful; from Yan Hui’s perspective, only Confucius is uniquely sorrowful. What Heaven bestows, one rejoices in and does not refuse—this is called rejoicing in Heaven. What fate ordains, one follows and does not resist—this is called knowing fate. To rejoice in Heaven yet not know fate, or to know fate yet not rejoice in Heaven, is insufficient to be free from sorrow. Though one who rejoices in Heaven and knows fate finds joy even in poverty, the joy of such a one is not in poverty or prosperity—this is why there is no sorrow. Yan Hui has attained this Dao, and thus, dwelling amid sorrows that others cannot bear, he remains unchanged in his joy.

Yet Confucius, having lived sixty years, underwent sixty transformations. What he once affirmed, he later deemed mistaken. To take rejoicing in Heaven and knowing fate as freedom from sorrow was his former affirmation. To regard rejoicing in Heaven and knowing fate as a sorrow of great magnitude is his present teaching. Compared to Confucius, Yan Hui grasped his conduct but not the reason for his conduct—hence he took up the zither and sang, yet could not share the sage’s sorrow.

Moreover, both are the words of a sage—how could there truly be contradiction or discord? Adapting to the times and suiting change, I merely ask that the present teaching be taken as correct. As for true joy and true knowledge, how can the words of past and present be distinguished?

Now I tell you the truth: cultivate the self, accept poverty or prosperity, know that going and coming are not of the self, and banish disturbance from the mind—this is what you call rejoicing in Heaven and knowing fate without sorrow. Formerly, I cultivated the *Odes* and *Documents*, rectified rites and music, intending to govern the world and bequeath it to future generations—not merely to cultivate myself or govern the state of Lu. Yet the rulers and ministers of Lu daily lost their proper order; benevolence and righteousness grew ever weaker, human nature ever more shallow. If this Dao cannot prevail in one state or one generation, how much less in the world and future ages?

I first realized that the *Odes*, *Documents*, rites, and music could not save the world from disorder, yet I did not know the means to reform them—this is the sorrow of one who rejoices in Heaven and knows fate. Nevertheless, I have grasped it now. The joy and knowledge of which I speak are not what the ancients meant by joy and knowledge. Without joy and without knowledge—this is true joy and true knowledge. Thus there is nothing not joyful, nothing not known, nothing not sorrowful, nothing not done. What need is there to abandon the *Odes*, *Documents*, rites, and music? Why reform them?

*Explanation:* The sage is the utmost of virtue and the perfection of the Dao. To call one a sage is to say that the mind is congealed and form released, with nothing cherished and nothing feared—what sorrow could there be? Even the benevolent can be free from sorrow, how much more Confucius, who embodied the sage’s consummation? If he were not free from sorrow, he could not be called a sage. To say the sage has sorrow is to misunderstand the sage.

Yet now, manifesting such great sorrow in countenance—this is because the sage is the linchpin of the ten thousand things, the one on whom all transformation depends, and who bears the weight of the world. If, by rejoicing in Heaven and knowing fate, I cultivate myself, accept poverty or prosperity, know that going and coming are not of the self, and still disturbances in the mind, then I am without sorrow—but how can I ensure that all the people are without sorrow? If the people are not entirely free from sorrow, how can the sage alone be without sorrow? His sorrow is not only for the present age but extends to future generations. The ages to come are endless, the people’s sorrows inexhaustible, and the sage’s sorrow likewise without end—is this not a sorrow of great magnitude?

Moreover, I cultivated the *Odes* and *Documents*, rectified rites and music, seeking to bring order, yet the Dao did not prevail. Seeing that the *Odes*, *Documents*, rites, and music could not save the world from disorder, I thought to reform them but did not know the way—how could I be without sorrow? Why is this? The Six Classics are the traces left by the former kings—are they the essence of those traces? The footprints are what the shoes produce, but are the footprints the shoes? Though the traces cannot be clung to, the shoes cannot be discarded either. Thus, the *Odes*, *Documents*, rites, and music—if abandoned, there is no means to govern; if followed, they cannot bring governance. Now, to take rejoicing in Heaven and knowing fate as freedom from sorrow is to abandon the shoes along with the traces—how then can governance be achieved?

Therefore, to call it rejoicing in Heaven is still to have something rejoiced in. To call it knowing fate is still to have something known. Having something rejoiced in necessarily entails sorrow; having something known necessarily entails omission. Only by attaining what is called true joy and true knowledge can there be no joy and no knowledge. Without joy and without knowledge, there is nothing not joyful, nothing not known, nothing not sorrowful, nothing not done—joy and sorrow both forgotten. Acting without acting, all is relinquished. The *Odes*, *Documents*, rites, and music need not be abandoned or reformed, yet the world can be governed and future ages bequeathed. This is what the *Book of Changes* means by "stirring the ten thousand things yet not sharing the sage’s sorrow." This is why Confucius edited the *Odes*, established the *Documents*, appended the *Book of Changes*, and composed the *Spring and Autumn*—earnestly transmitting these teachings.

Yan Hui bowed northward and said, "I too have grasped it." He went out and told Zigong. Zigong was lost in bewilderment, returned home, and brooded for seven days without sleep or food, until his bones stood out. Yan Hui went again to explain it to him, whereupon he returned to Confucius’s gate, strumming the zither and chanting the classics all day without cease.

*Explanation:* Yan Hui once asked Confucius to let him go to Wei, but Confucius thought it perilous, saying, "You would likely go and be punished." Was this perhaps because he had not yet grasped the meaning of rejoicing in Heaven and knowing fate as entailing a sorrow of great magnitude?

chunks.original_text: 至於谓其用之则行，舍之则藏，同於孔子，其以有得於此而然尔。 至於子贡，虽曰智足以知圣人，於圣人之天道则不得而闻也，故至此则茫然自失。 虽然，深思历时而不变，至於不寝不食而骨立，则都忘我体，融会於理，可告以圣人之道矣。 故一得颜子之喻，则释然反夫子之门，终其身焉。 弦歌则得其乐，诵书则亦知诗书之不必弃也。 陈大夫聘鲁，私见叔孙氏。 叔孙氏曰：吾国有圣人。 曰：非孔丘耶？ 曰：是也。 何以知其圣乎？ 叔孙氏曰：吾尝闻之颜回，曰：孔丘能废心而用形。 陈大夫曰：吾国亦有圣人，子弗知乎？ 曰：圣人孰谓？ 曰：老聃之弟子有亢仓子者，得聃之道，能以耳视而目听。 鲁侯闻之大惊，使上卿厚礼而致之。 亢仓子应聘而至。 鲁侯卑辞请问之。 亢仓子曰：传之者妄。 我能视听不用耳目，不能易耳目之用。 鲁侯曰：此增异矣，其道奈何？ 寡人终愿闻之。 解曰：人之见闻，不离形体。 虽圣人亦无以异於人也，特圣人所以为见闻寄於形体以发其明，不尽循於形体也。 唯其不循形体，故能废心； 唯其寄於形体，故犹用形。 废心，即亢仓子之视听不用耳目； 用形，即亢仓子之不能易耳目之用。 以亢仓子之为圣不殊於孔子之圣，则知孔子之道无异於老君之道也。 亢仓子曰：我体合於心，心合於气，气合於神，神合於无。 解曰：太初有无，无有无名，而神运乎其中矣。 太初兆而为气之始，气委和而有生，有生斯有心，造化之均付於人者如此。 所以有狂圣之异者，以其所合不同也。 圣人则每陟愈上而合於无，合於无则无往而不合矣。 众人则每降愈下而合於物，合於物则无适而不碍矣。 体合於心则忘其形体，心合於气则忘其思虑，气合於神则浑然一气，圣而不可知矣。 然而神虽妙犹未离有，至於神合於无则同於太虚，於大不终，於小不遗，万物莫能逃其鉴矣。 其有介然之有，唯然之音，虽远在八荒之外，近在眉睫之内，来千我者，我必知之。 乃不知是我七孔四支之所觉，心腹六藏之所知，其自知而已矣。 鲁侯大悦。 佗日以告仲尼，仲尼笑而不答。 解曰：八荒之外，至远也，山河布列，万物纷错，视听之所不周。 眉睫之内，至近也，腑藏居中，窍穴居外，知见不能自见。 神合於无，则形体融虚，物象销顶，浑然太虚。 虽么虫之微，可视犹嵩山之阿，况於介然之有乎？ 虽么虫之声，可听犹雷霆之响，况於唯然之音乎？ 老君曰：其出弥远，其知弥少。 义协於此。 虽然，圣人不务多知也，来千我者则知之尔，唯其不务外知，是以莫觉莫知，其知自然，无所不知也。 如其所知得之於觉，则不离於体，得之於知，则不出乎思。 又焉能无不毕知哉？ 亢仓子之言尽之矣，莫逆於心而不可以容声矣，是以鲁侯以告仲尼，仲尼笑而不答。 商太宰见孔子曰：丘圣者欤？ 孔子曰：圣则丘何敢，然则丘博学多识者也。 商太宰曰：三王圣者欤？ 孔子曰：三王善任智勇者，圣则丘不知。 曰：五帝圣者欤？ 孔子曰：五帝善任仁义者，圣则丘弗知。 曰：三皇圣者欤？ 孔子曰：三皇善任因时者，圣则丘弗知。 商太宰大骇， 解曰：道一而已，皇降而帝，尧以是而传之舜，舜以是而传之禹。 汤文武皆古圣人也，然而羲皇之简朴，尧舜之逊，汤武之争，孔子之素王，皆其不得已因时而应世，所以为圣者隐矣。
chunks.translated_text:
As for Yan Hui’s saying that "when employed, he acts; when set aside, he withdraws"—this being the same as Confucius—it was because he had attained this understanding. As for Zigong, though his wisdom sufficed to recognize the sage, he had not yet heard of the sage’s Heavenly Dao, and thus fell into bewilderment and self-loss. Nevertheless, his deep reflection over time, enduring without sleep or food until his bones stood out, showed that he had forgotten his self and merged with principle, making it possible to instruct him in the sage’s Way. Thus, upon receiving Yan Hui’s explanation, he released his doubts and returned to the Master’s gate, where he spent his days strumming the zither and chanting the classics. In his music, he found joy; in his recitations, he understood that the *Odes* and *Documents* need not be discarded.

A minister from Chen, on a diplomatic mission to Lu, privately visited the house of the Shusun clan. The Shusun lord said, "There is a sage in our state." The minister asked, "Is it not Kong Qiu?" "It is," he replied. "How do you know he is a sage?" The Shusun lord said, "I once heard Yan Hui say, ‘Kong Qiu can set aside the mind and employ the body.’"

The minister from Chen said, "There is also a sage in our state—did you not know?" "Who is this sage?" he asked. "Among Lao Dan’s disciples was one named Kang Cangzi, who attained Lao Dan’s Dao and could see with his ears and hear with his eyes." When the Duke of Lu heard this, he was greatly astonished and sent his highest minister with lavish gifts to invite him. Kang Cangzi accepted the invitation and arrived. The Duke of Lu humbly questioned him. Kang Cangzi said, "The transmission is false. I can see and hear without using my ears and eyes, but I cannot alter the functions of ears and eyes."

The Duke of Lu said, "This is even more extraordinary—what is your Way? I earnestly wish to hear it."

*Explanation:* Human perception and hearing do not depart from the body. Even the sage has no means to differ from others in this; only the sage’s perception and hearing rely on the body to manifest clarity, not being entirely bound by it. Precisely because he is not bound by the body, he can set aside the mind; precisely because he relies on the body, he still employs its form. "Setting aside the mind" corresponds to Kang Cangzi’s seeing and hearing without using ears and eyes; "employing the form" corresponds to his inability to alter the functions of ears and eyes. Since Kang Cangzi’s sageliness is no different from Confucius’s, we know that Confucius’s Dao is no different from the Old Master’s Dao.

Kang Cangzi said, "My body unites with the mind, the mind unites with qi, qi unites with spirit, and spirit unites with nothingness."

*Explanation:* In the Great Beginning, there was nothingness—nothingness without name—yet spirit moved within it. The Great Beginning presaged the inception of qi; qi harmonized and gave rise to life, and with life came the mind. The balance of creation is bestowed upon humanity in this way. The difference between the mad and the sage lies in what they unite with. The sage ever ascends and unites with nothingness; united with nothingness, there is nowhere he does not unite. The common person ever descends and unites with things; united with things, there is nowhere he is not obstructed. When the body unites with the mind, one forgets the form; when the mind unites with qi, one forgets thought; when qi unites with spirit, one becomes a single undifferentiated qi, sagely and unknowable. Yet though spirit is wondrous, it has not departed from being. Only when spirit unites with nothingness does it merge with the Great Void, neither ending in the vast nor neglecting the minute, with no thing escaping its mirror. Whether it be the faintest existence or the faintest sound—though distant in the eight wilds or near at the brows and lashes—whatever comes to me, I must know it. Yet this is not the awareness of the seven apertures and four limbs, nor the knowledge of the six viscera within the chest and abdomen; it is self-knowing alone.

The Duke of Lu was overjoyed. Another day, he told this to Zhongni, who smiled but did not answer.

*Explanation:* The eight wilds are the farthest reaches, where mountains and rivers spread and the ten thousand things intermingle, beyond the scope of sight and hearing. The brows and lashes are the nearest, where the viscera reside within and the orifices without, yet knowledge and perception cannot perceive themselves. When spirit unites with nothingness, the body merges with emptiness, and the appearances of things dissolve into the apex—all becomes the Great Void. Though the tiniest insect may be as visible as the slopes of Mount Song, how much more so the faintest existence? Though the faintest sound may be as audible as thunder, how much more so the faintest tone? The Old Master said, "The farther it extends, the less one knows." This principle accords with that. Nevertheless, the sage does not strive for excessive knowledge; whatever comes to me, I know it. Only by not pursuing external knowledge does one remain unaware and unknowing, yet one’s knowledge arises naturally, with nothing unknown. If one’s knowledge were obtained through perception, it would not depart from the body; if obtained through thought, it would not transcend reflection. How then could one know all without exception? Kang Cangzi’s words exhaust the matter—so perfectly aligned with the heart that no sound could contain it. Thus, when the Duke of Lu told this to Zhongni, Zhongni smiled but did not answer.

The Grand Steward of Shang visited Confucius and asked, "Is Qiu a sage?" Confucius said, "How would Qiu dare claim sageliness? Yet Qiu is one who has broadly studied and widely retained knowledge." The Grand Steward asked, "Were the Three Kings sages?" Confucius said, "The Three Kings were good at employing wisdom and courage—whether they were sages, Qiu does not know." He asked, "Were the Five Emperors sages?" Confucius said, "The Five Emperors were good at employing benevolence and righteousness—whether they were sages, Qiu does not know." He asked, "Were the Three Sovereigns sages?" Confucius said, "The Three Sovereigns were good at following the times—whether they were sages, Qiu does not know."

The Grand Steward of Shang was greatly astonished.

*Explanation:* The Dao is one alone. From the Sovereigns it descended to the Emperors; Yao transmitted it to Shun in this way, and Shun to Yu. Tang, Wen, and Wu were all ancient sages. Yet the simplicity of Fuxi, the yielding of Yao and Shun, the contention of Tang and Wu, and Confucius’s uncrowned kingship—all were responses to the times out of necessity, and thus the sageliness within them was concealed.

chunks.original_text: 故孔子於商太宰之问，在己则曰不敢，於人则曰不知。 虽然，善任因时则道显，善任仁义则德着，善任智勇则业富，博学多识则穷理尽性，皆圣人之事也，特不敢知而已。 且皇降而帝，帝降而王。 商太宰则王者之佐尔，彼其於帝王之治，方且祖述宪章之不暇，遽而告以弗知为帝为皇之圣，彼又鸟能无惊乎哉？ 曰：然则孰者为圣？ 孔子动容有间，曰：西方之人，有圣者焉。 解曰：所谓圣人者，即皇之道，帝之德，王之业，孔子之集大成也。 孔子语商太宰者，亦皆圣人之事也。 其所以不居其圣者，盖所以圣则与於神而不可知矣。 圣人作而兆於变化，则为万物之所睹。 而所以为圣者隐矣，可知其治而不知其道矣。 商太宰乃欲外圣人而求圣，惑亦甚矣。 孔子动容，将正容以悟之也。 动容有间而不悟，是终不能知言之谓也，於是乃告之曰：西方之人有圣者焉。 所谓西方之人者，亦以圣人之不离於神，天之本宗而未兆於变化者为言尔。 盖西为复命反性之方也，且天道自西而之北，至北而后为复命之至。 《列子》语圣人之道每托言於西方者，方袪衰周文胜之弊，欲斯民去华而就实，故言主於西，亦以此言化人之所从来，老聃之所徂往也。 如至於北之辩，则又将为震之出矣。 此其言之旨欤。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus, when Confucius was questioned by the Grand Steward of Shang, regarding himself he said, "I dare not," and regarding others, "I do not know." Nevertheless, those who skillfully follow the times manifest the Dao; those who skillfully employ benevolence and righteousness make virtue evident; those who skillfully apply wisdom and courage enrich their achievements; and those who broadly study and amass knowledge exhaust principle and fulfill their nature—all are the affairs of the sage, merely that he dare not claim to know.

Moreover, the Sovereigns descended to the Emperors, and the Emperors descended to the Kings. The Grand Steward of Shang was but an assistant to the kings; how could he, still occupied with following and upholding their governance, suddenly be told that one does not know whether the Emperors or Sovereigns were sages? How could he not be astonished?

He asked, "Then who is a sage?" Confucius changed his countenance and paused, then said, "In the West, there is a sage."

*Explanation:* The so-called sage is the Dao of the Sovereigns, the virtue of the Emperors, the achievements of the Kings, and the culmination of Confucius. What Confucius told the Grand Steward of Shang were all the affairs of the sage. The reason he did not claim sageliness was that the sage, in his sageliness, partakes of the numinous and is unknowable. When the sage acts and presages transformation, he becomes visible to all things. Yet what makes him a sage remains concealed; one may know his governance but not his Dao.

The Grand Steward of Shang sought the sage outside the sage—his confusion was profound. Confucius changed his countenance, intending to rectify his demeanor and enlighten him. When the change in countenance and pause brought no understanding, it became clear he would never grasp the words. Thus, Confucius told him, "In the West, there is a sage."

The so-called "person of the West" refers to the sage who does not depart from the numinous, the root origin of Heaven that has not yet presaged transformation. The West is the direction of returning to life and reverting to one’s nature. Moreover, the Way of Heaven moves from the West to the North; only upon reaching the North is the return to life complete. When *Liezi* speaks of the Dao of the sage, it often alludes to the West, aiming to dispel the decadence of the declining Zhou and the excesses of culture, urging the people to abandon superficiality and embrace substance. Thus, it speaks of the West as the origin of transformation and the destination of Lao Dan’s departure.

As for the distinction of the North, it will soon give rise to the arousal of *Zhen*. Such is the purport of these words.

chunks.original_text: 不治而不乱，不言而自信，不化而自行，荡荡乎民无能名焉。 丘疑其为圣，弗知真为圣欤、真不圣欤？ 解曰：天下本无事，彼民有常然。 不忍一世之伤而治之，斯謷万世之息而莫之救矣。 是故应帝王者以道，观言命物之化所免也。 然而有言则必有疑之者矣，有化则亦有拂之者矣，名存於治乱，则其去圣逾远矣，唯荡荡乎民无能名者为足以拟圣也。 老君曰：道常无名无始，曰道不当名。 圣人者，道之至也，可名则非道矣。 由伏牺而至孔子，其应世之迹不几於卖名声於天下者乎？ 宜孔子不知其圣也。 然而以无能名为圣，既可名以无名，亦既有矣，安得为无能名？ 盖终不可得而名者，道之真名之以无能名而托其无者，圣人之不得已。 故孔子虽曰西方之人有圣者焉，终亦云弗知其真为圣而真不圣也。 虽然，所谓无能名者，非以虚无无为离於称谓为无也，故曰虽为而无为之之累，若可名而无可名之实尔。 故孔子尝以荡荡乎民无能名称尧矣，不废其巍巍之成功也。 观孔子之语商太宰者，始也不知其圣，终亦疑其为圣，不知其迹於其始，莫知其妙於其终，圣而不可知，於是乎在。 商太宰默然心计曰：孔丘欺我哉。 解曰：有方而后可欺。 商太宰於孔子之言，辩不足以屈其理，诚不足以信其道，故心计之以为我欺也。 子夏问孔子曰：颜回之为人奚若？ 子曰：回之仁，贤於丘也。 曰：子贡之为人奚若？ 子曰：赐之辩，贤於丘也。 曰：子路之为人奚若？ 子曰：由之勇，贤於丘也。 曰：子张之为人奚若？ 子曰：师之庄，贤於丘也。 子夏避席而问曰：然则四子者何为事夫子？ 曰：居。 吾语汝。
chunks.translated_text:
Without governance yet without disorder, without speech yet self-trusting, without transformation yet self-acting—so vast and boundless that the people cannot name it. I, Qiu, suspect this to be sageliness, yet do not know whether it is truly sageliness or truly not sageliness.

To explain: The world originally had no affairs; those people abided in constant spontaneity. If one cannot bear the harms of an age and thus governs it, one disrupts the repose of ten thousand generations without hope of remedy. Therefore, those who respond as emperors and kings do so through the Dao, observing the transformations of words and the destinies of things to avoid entanglement. Yet where there are words, there will be those who doubt them; where there is transformation, there will be those who resist it. If names exist amid order and chaos, one strays ever farther from sageliness. Only that which is so vast and boundless that the people cannot name it may be likened to sageliness.

Old Master said: "The Dao is ever nameless and without beginning," for the Dao ought not to be named. The sage is the utmost of the Dao; if it can be named, it is not the Dao. From Fuxi to Confucius, have their responses to the world not been nearly akin to selling fame and reputation across the realm? No wonder Confucius did not recognize his own sageliness.

Yet if one takes the inability to be named as sageliness, then to name it "nameless" is already to have named it—how can it remain unnameable? That which ultimately cannot be named is the true nature of the Dao. To name it "unnameable" and thereby allude to its namelessness is the sage’s unavoidable concession. Thus, though Confucius said, "In the West there is a sage," he ultimately declared he did not know whether it was truly sageliness or truly not sageliness.

Nevertheless, this "unnameable" does not mean emptiness, non-action, or detachment from all designation as nothingness. Rather, it is to act without being burdened by action, as if nameable yet without the substance of a name. Thus, Confucius once praised Yao as "so vast and boundless that the people could not name him," yet did not deny his towering achievements.

Consider Confucius’ words to the Grand Steward of Shang: at first, he did not know him to be a sage; in the end, he still doubted whether he was a sage. None knew his traces at the beginning, nor his subtleties at the end—sageliness that cannot be known, therein it resides. The Grand Steward of Shang fell silent and pondered in his heart, "Kong Qiu has deceived me!"

To explain: Only where there is a fixed standard can deception occur. The Grand Steward of Shang, confronted with Confucius’ words, found his eloquence insufficient to refute their principle and his sincerity insufficient to trust his Dao, so he pondered in his heart that he had been deceived.

Zixia asked Confucius, "What sort of person is Yan Hui?"
The Master said, "Hui’s benevolence surpasses my own."
"What sort of person is Zigong?"
"The acuity of Ci surpasses my own."
"What sort of person is Zilu?"
"The courage of You surpasses my own."
"What sort of person is Zizhang?"
"The solemnity of Shi surpasses my own."

Zixia rose from his mat and asked, "Then why do these four serve you?"
The Master said, "Sit. I will tell you."

chunks.original_text: 夫回能仁而不能反，赐能辩而不能讷，由能勇而不能怯，师能庄而不能同。 兼四子之有以易吾，吾弗许也。 此其所以事吾而不贰也。 解曰：诸子之德，譬犹阴阳； 圣人之道，譬犹冲气。 冲气微於阴阳，阴阳资於冲气。 语四子之有皆贤於夫子，兼四子之有则不许其易夫子。 然则其贤也乃其所以为偏，其不及也乃其所以为妙，此四子所以事夫子而不贰也。 子列子既师壶丘子林，友伯氏瞀人，乃居南郭。 从之处者，日数而不及。 解曰：列子既进二子之道，乘风而归，则所以处己者至矣，尽矣。 列子不忍以夫子之道独善其身也，於是乃居南郭也。 南明方，郭邑中也。 既已出而趋物之会，则不能使人无保汝，而户外之履满矣。 虽然，子列子亦微焉。 朝朝相与辩，无不闻。 而与南郭子连墙二十年，不相谒请，相遇於道，目若不相见者。 门之徒役以为子列子与南郭子有敌不疑。 解曰：谓之南郭子，则体道之妙，居尘而不染者，是所以与子列子为连墙也。 二子之道圆通妙合，常相与以不来而来，不见而见，又奚以相谒请为哉？ 非特不相谒请也，虽相遇於道，目若不相见者。 夫学道者至於目击而道存，亦已至矣。 然待於目击，犹未离见，唯相遇而目若不相见，则离於知见。 无相无作，彼我都忘，列子之道尽於是矣。 故曰：子列子亦微焉。 微以言不离於道，心之小而妙也。 然则朝朝相与辩，无不闻，岂好辩哉？ 以夫从之处者故不得已尔。 门之徒役方且见列子於言辩之间，故以其不相谒请为有敌而不疑也。 有自楚来者，问子列子曰：先生与南郭子奚敌？ 子列子曰：南郭子貌充心虚，耳无闻，目无见，口无言，心无知，形无惕。 往将奚为？ 解曰：貌充者，修身而形不衰也。 心虚者，忘心而物不留也。 耳无闻者，自闻而已。 目无见者，自见而已。 口无言，出言不言也。 心无知，真知无知也。 形无惕，都无所畏忌也。 若是者，师资兼忘，其往也，将奚为哉？ 虽然，试与汝偕往。 阅弟子四十人同行。 解曰：列子既已言南郭子之妙矣，恐其徒役之重惑於至道，故与之偕往，阅而实之以见也。 弟子四十人同行，犹所谓与人偕来之众也。 见南郭子，果若欺魄焉，而不可与接。 顾视子列子，形神不相偶，而不可与群。 解曰：神生形，形成神。 形神偶合，人之所以有生也。 形神不相偶，所谓有人之形无人之情也，是欺魄之类也。 欺魄，土偶人也。 若是者，遗物离人而立於独，故不可与接，不可与群。 南郭子俄而指子列子之弟子末行者与言，衎衎然若专直而在雄者。 子列子之徒骇之。 反舍，咸有疑色。 解曰：夫乾其静也专，其动也直。 衎衎，言其和也。 衎衎然若专直而在雄者，则言若体乾之道，尸万物之化，而纳之大和者。 俄而指弟子之末行者与言，则遇感而应，非有心也。 其道大，故骇之。 信不足有不信，故反合，咸有疑色，与退而省其私亦足以发者异矣。 子列子曰：得意者无言，进知者亦无言。 用无言为言亦言，无知为知亦知。 无言与不言，无知与不知，亦言亦知。 亦无所不言，亦无所不知，亦无所言，亦无所知。 如斯而已，汝奚妄骇哉？ 解曰：书不尽言，言不尽意，故得意者无言。 知者不言，言者不知，故进知者亦无言。
chunks.translated_text:
Hui excels in benevolence but cannot return to simplicity; Ci excels in eloquence but cannot be reticent; You excels in courage but cannot be timid; Shi excels in solemnity but cannot be harmonious. Were I to exchange my own qualities for the sum of theirs, I would not consent. This is why they serve me without divided loyalty.

To explain: The virtues of these disciples are like yin and yang; the Dao of the sage is like the harmonizing qi. The harmonizing qi is subtler than yin and yang, yet yin and yang draw upon it. Though each of the four possesses qualities surpassing my own, I would not consent to exchange my own for the sum of theirs. Thus, their excellence is precisely what makes them partial, and their deficiency is precisely what makes them wondrous—this is why they serve me without divided loyalty.

Master Liezi, having taken Huqiu Zilin as his teacher and befriended Boshi Maoren, then dwelled in Nanguo. Those who followed him there came daily in such numbers that they could not be counted.

To explain: After Liezi had advanced in the Dao of these two masters and returned riding the wind, his own cultivation had reached its utmost perfection. Yet he could not bear to keep the Master’s Dao solely for his own benefit, so he took up residence in Nanguo. Nanguo was a bustling district within the city walls. Once he had emerged to engage with the world, he could not prevent people from flocking to him, and the sandals outside his door piled up. Nevertheless, Master Liezi remained subtle in his way.

Each morning, he debated with others, and there was nothing he did not hear. Yet for twenty years, he shared a wall with Nanguozi and never paid him a formal visit. When they met on the road, their eyes seemed not to see each other. The disciples and servants in his household took it for granted that Liezi and Nanguozi were rivals.

To explain: Nanguozi embodied the subtlety of the Dao, dwelling amid the dust without being stained by it—this was why he and Liezi shared a wall. The Dao of these two masters was perfectly round and wondrously attuned, ever meeting without seeking, seeing without appearing. Why, then, would they need to pay formal visits? Not only did they not visit each other, but even when they met on the road, their eyes seemed not to see. For those who study the Dao, to have the Dao present at a glance is already the utmost. Yet to rely on such a glance is still not free from perception. Only when they met and their eyes seemed not to see was perception transcended. Without mutual engagement, without action, self and other both forgotten—Liezi’s Dao was perfected in this. Thus it is said: Master Liezi was also subtle. Subtle in that his words never departed from the Dao, his heart refined and wondrous.

Yet if each morning he debated with others and heard everything, was this love of debate? It was only because of those who followed him that he could not avoid it. His disciples and servants, seeing Liezi engaged in debate, took his lack of formal visits to Nanguozi as proof of rivalry.

A man from Chu came and asked Liezi, “In what way is your master a match for Nanguozi?”
Liezi said, “Nanguozi’s appearance is full, his heart empty. His ears do not hear, his eyes do not see, his mouth does not speak, his heart does not know, his form is without fear. What could he possibly do?”

To explain: “Appearance full” means his cultivation preserved his form without decline. “Heart empty” means he forgot his heart and things did not linger. “Ears do not hear” means he heard only himself. “Eyes do not see” means he saw only himself. “Mouth does not speak” means his words were not mere words. “Heart does not know” means true knowing is without knowing. “Form without fear” means he had no apprehensions or taboos. One like this has forgotten both teacher and disciple. What, then, could he do when he went forth?

“Nevertheless,” Liezi said, “let us go together.” He gathered forty disciples and set out.

To explain: Liezi had already spoken of Nanguozi’s subtlety, but fearing his followers would remain deeply confused about the ultimate Dao, he went with them to witness it firsthand. The forty disciples who accompanied him were like the many who come together with others.

When they saw Nanguozi, he seemed indeed like a lifeless effigy, impossible to engage. Looking back at Liezi, his form and spirit were not paired, and he could not be grouped with others.

To explain: Spirit gives rise to form, and form gives rise to spirit. The pairing of form and spirit is what gives rise to human life. When form and spirit are not paired, it is as if one has the form of a human but not the feelings—this is the kind of lifeless effigy Nanguozi resembled. A lifeless effigy is a clay figurine. One like this stands apart from things and people, solitary in his uniqueness. Thus he could not be engaged, nor could he be grouped with others.

Suddenly, Nanguozi pointed to one of Liezi’s disciples in the rear rank and spoke with him, his manner joyful and forthright, as if he were the very embodiment of strength. Liezi’s disciples were astonished. When they returned home, all wore expressions of doubt.

To explain: In its stillness, the Qian hexagram is single-minded; in its movement, it is direct. *Kankan* describes its harmony. To be *kankan* yet forthright, as if embodying the strength of Qian, is to embody the Dao of Qian, presiding over the transformations of the myriad things and guiding them into great harmony. Suddenly pointing to a disciple in the rear rank and speaking with him was a response to encounter, not a deliberate act. His Dao was vast, so they were astonished. When trust is insufficient, there is distrust. Thus, upon returning, they all wore expressions of doubt—quite different from those who withdraw to reflect privately and thereby gain insight.

Liezi said: “Those who grasp the meaning do not speak; those who advance in knowledge also do not speak. To use non-speech as speech is still speech; to use non-knowing as knowing is still knowing. Non-speech and not speaking, non-knowing and not knowing—these are also speech and knowing. They are also without anything not spoken, without anything not known, and also without anything spoken, without anything known. It is only thus. Why this groundless astonishment?”

To explain: Writing cannot fully express words, and words cannot fully express meaning—thus those who grasp the meaning do not speak. The knowing do not speak; those who speak do not know—thus those who advance in knowledge also do not speak.
